content: Flower (chrysanthemum)-based tea infusion **Chrysanthemum tea** is a flower-based [infusion](/wiki/Infusion) beverage made from the [chrysanthemum](/wiki/Chrysanthemum) flowers of the species *[Chrysanthemum morifolium](/wiki/Chrysanthemum_morifolium)* or *[Chrysanthemum indicum](/wiki/Chrysanthemum_indicum)*, which are most popular throughout [East](/wiki/East_Asia) and [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia). First cultivated in [China](/wiki/Imperial_China) as a [herb](/wiki/Herb) as early as the 1500 BCE, Chrysanthemum became popularized as a tea during the [Song dynasty](/wiki/Song_dynasty). In Chinese tradition, once a pot of chrysanthemum tea has been drunk, hot water is typically added again to the flowers in the pot (producing a tea that is slightly less strong); this process is often repeated several times. To prepare the tea, chrysanthemum flowers (usually dried) are steeped in hot water (usually 90 to 95 degrees Celsius after cooling from a boil) in either a [teapot](/wiki/Teapot), cup, or glass; often [rock sugar](/wiki/Rock_candy) or [cane sugar](/wiki/Sucrose) is also added. The resulting drink is transparent and ranges from pale to bright yellow in color, with a floral aroma. ## Varieties Part of a series on[Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Chinese_cuisine)[Regional cuisines](/wiki/Chinese_regional_cuisine)Four Great Traditions - China portal - Taiwan portal - Hong Kong portal - Singapore portal - Malaysia portal - v - t - e ### China Several varieties of chrysanthemum, ranging from white to pale or bright yellow in color, are used for tea. These include: - *Huángshān-gòngjú* (黄山贡菊, literally "Yellow Mountain tribute chrysanthemum"); also called simply *gòngjú* (贡菊) - *Hángbáijú* (杭白菊), originating from [Tongxiang](/wiki/Tongxiang), near [Hangzhou](/wiki/Hangzhou); also called simply *Hángjú*, (杭菊) - *Chújú* (滁菊), originating from the [Chuzhou](/wiki/Chuzhou) district of [Anhui](/wiki/Anhui) - *Bójú* (亳菊), originating in the [Bozhou](/wiki/Bozhou) district of [Anhui](/wiki/Anhui) Of these, the first two are most popular. Some varieties feature a prominent yellow [flower head](/wiki/Head_(botany)) while others do not. ### Korea *Gukhwacha* (국화차; 菊花茶) is made from dried [Indian chrysanthemum](/wiki/Chrysanthemum_indicum) collected before fully opened. - Chrysanthemum tea – The flowers are blanched in [bamboo salt](/wiki/Jugyeom) water, carefully washed in cold water and drained on kitchen towel. The drained flowers are covered with [hanji](/wiki/Korean_paper) and dried in an [ondol](/wiki/Ondol) (floor-heated) room. When served, three to four flowers are added to hot water. - Honey chrysanthemum tea – The flowers are carefully washed and dried, then preserved in honey for three to four weeks. When served, the preserved flowers are added to hot water. - Medicinal chrysanthemum tea – The flowers are washed carefully, steamed using the water mixed with [herbal decoction](/wiki/Traditional_Korean_medicine) and dried. When fully dried, they are steamed again, and dried again. This process is repeated nine times. Water to decoction ratio can be 8:1, and the decoction is usually made of dried roots of [white woodland peony](/wiki/Paeonia_obovata), steamed and dried roots of [rehmannia](/wiki/Rehmannia_glutinosa), dried roots of [Korean angelica](/wiki/Angelica_gigas), and dried roots of [lovage](/wiki/Lovage). ## Commercial availability Although typically prepared at home, chrysanthemum tea is sold in many Asian restaurants (particularly Chinese), and in various [Asian grocery stores](/wiki/Asian_supermarket) in and outside Asia in canned or packed form, as either a whole flower or [teabag](/wiki/Teabag) presentation. Juice boxes of chrysanthemum tea may be sold. ## Gallery - [Chinese herb tea](/wiki/Chinese_herb_tea) - [List of Chinese teas](/wiki/List_of_Chinese_teas) - [List of Chinese inventions](/wiki/List_of_Chinese_inventions) - [Traditional Korean tea](/wiki/Traditional_Korean_tea) - *[Xia Sang Ju](/wiki/Xia_Sang_Ju)* Portals: - Drink - Asia
